text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Albert Smith
Address: 284-6th Ave., Medicine Hat
Birthplace: Toronto, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1901
Where did you set up housekeeping? Prairie Albert, Ont.
Where had you been living before that? Butte, Montana, P.O. 1882
For how many people did you prepare meals? One
How far was it to your nearest store? Two miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Any time
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
In 1901 practically any type of food was available in Prairie Albert.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? H.B.C. Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50 per 100 lbs.
How much did you use graham flour? 100 lbs.
Whole wheat flour? 100 lbs.
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 100 miles
What other grain products did you use? Rolled oats, cornmeal, buckwheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER DAYS: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Mrs. Allison
Address: 224 5th Street, Medicine Hat, Alberta
Date: June 1953

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

That year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1901
Where did you set up housekeeping? Medicine Hat
Where had you been living before that? Medicine Hat
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Groceries

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand or white flour did you use in the early years? M.B.G. Hom
In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lb. per roll
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50 per roll
How much did you use Graham flour? 10 lb. per roll
Was flour milled locally? Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.75 per bag
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, Whole Wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? By hand

The answers are written in cursive handwriting.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 10 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edward's Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? 1920.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From farmers.

What was the price of butter? 15 cents.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, pork, lamb.

How did you get fresh meat? From the shop.

How often did you get fresh meat? All the time.

How did you preserve meat? Salted.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood?

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? In summer for food.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? (Lb. lbs.)

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? (Lb. lbs.)

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? (Brand)

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? (Size)

At what price? (Price)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? (Method)

Was there a creamery? (Yes/No)

What was the price of butter? (Price)

Did you pack eggs for winter? (Yes/No)

Did you make butter? (Yes/No)

What kind of cheese? (Type)

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? (Method)

How did you get fresh meat? (Method)

How often did you get fresh meat? (Frequency)

How did you preserve meat? (Method)

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? (Yes/No)

If so what year was it organized? (Year)

Did you use game? (Yes/No)

For how long? (Duration)

What part did fish play in the family diet? (Importance)

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? (Type)

Kind of? (Type)
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? H.B.C. Co. 6c. At what price? 42¢. 6¢.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) 1 lb. 5¢. Ground.

Price? 40¢. What other beverages were used? Water.

VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25¢ in 1901.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Tennessee.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes Cabbage Carrots Onions

Turnips Beets

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? None.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk.

What weight? 25 lb. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? In bulk.

What was the price of prunes?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, peaches, apricots, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods? All. (Dried fruits, dried berries, canned, cranberry and other berries.)

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

What year did you first preserve meat by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? We preserved fruit and vegetables by canning.

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar?
6. Beverages

What kind of tea did you buy? H.B. Co. (tea or ground) 4.00¢/lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) 4.00¢/lb.

Price? 4.00¢/lb.

What other beverages were used?

Vegetables and dried fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25¢/bushel

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 1 lb.

How did you buy peaches? (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk

What weight? 1 lb.

How did the grocer handle peaches (by box)? No

What was the price of peaches? 3¢/lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, raisins, currants or others)

Preserving

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No

Peas? No

Beans? No

Other foods? No

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1920

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1920

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

To what extent? Yes

Did you make your own vinegar?

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? My mother for Brewer's Yeast always -
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes... Using starter? David price I
Using hops? don't enough & may buy I used it rising hot water.
Did you buy baking powder? Yes........ Baking soda? Yes........
Cream of tartar? Yes........ Did you make your own baking powder? No

10. BAKING
What type of yeast did you use? My mother for Brewer's Yeast always
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes...Using starter...Always used flour
Did you buy baking powder? Yes...Using cream of tartar...Yes...Baking soda
Did you make your own baking powder?

110
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|-------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|

| Canned sardines             |                                        |                               |                                                 |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, August) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ................................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) .................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1902 when I moved away from Prairie Allen to Medicine Hat there was no change in water supply. Five or six years later many water was available.
12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Lake, river, spring)

How far was this water from your house?

How was it brought to the house?

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started keeping records, giving dates where possible.

In 1902 (or 1903) we moved away from our old home in Waterford to Medicius Hall, thus we no longer had water supply. We now rely on our own tanks for our water needs.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought ours.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Electric and Royal Ivy.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From the woods, wood yard, wood lot.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When I began to cook in 1902 everyone used wood in their stove and furnace. By 1903 or 1904 we had begun using coal especially for the furnace.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) When my parents lived here, P.A. Wilf, they had a clock stove and chimney pipe.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) Never ever used one.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Guinney.

What year was it purchased? 1881. Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homesteader)

Jars, kettles, pans, and coffee pots.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

We used all of these.

When did you first see enamel ware? About 1890.

Aluminum?
13. SOAP
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL
What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel? Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Did you use an outdoor fireplace or take over? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? Price?

What year was it purchased? (Iron, copper, tin, brass)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, brass)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Then did you first use enamel ware? Aluminum?

16. KITCHEN APPLIANCES

Pans, pots, kettles, etc.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

When I was a child and in fact prior to 1942 our foods were packaged. We bought sugar, tea, coffee, prunes, raisins, currants, peels, spices, pepper, salt, dried fruits all by the pound. Green peas kept better, sealed and weighed that way. Dried tomatoes and currants in barrels - as well as hard tack.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

I remember very far back when I was 5 years old. Rebellion took place likely the events were very important. We had oatmeal porridge, coffee bread rolls, olives (or beans). It was hard to make as it was made on a wood fire and syrup. Dinner at noon - meat, roast beef (which to you was 18 cents). Potatoes, turnips, cranberry pie, tea and milk, tea at 6 p.m. We had cold meat, fried potatoes, raspberries, strawberries, jam. Bread rolls, a tin pie. Mrs. Vincent - how much my mother was famous.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

I cannot remember when any Christmas dinner was much different than in later years - turkey, vegetables, plum pudding and mince pie - and always dumplings made with head dough. In 1945 there was present my father and mother - Douglas (myself), Edith, Ethel, Harry so he was born in 1946 killed in France 1948. Lot more fun and a puzzle from the office who had no home like Pbt Burns.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No never - we were flour, sugar once I remember but there was always a great plenty of flour, meal, tea, coffee - and dried fruit in my day.
16. WASTE DISPOSAL CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wastepaper and containers used.

With the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

I remember very few menus. The china was very nice. We had a lot of meat, pork, ham, or a little fish and maybe a little meat. We had to make our own bread, tea and milk. Tea at 6 p.m.

Potatoes, lima beans, cranberry pie, ice cream.

Bread rolls, omelet, 1947, plus honey. For breakfast, we had toast, jam, eggs, bacon, coffee.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? List those present and give the menu.

Christmas dinner John and Christine dinner was served December 25th. Turkey was always served. Plan pudding and mince pie and always apple fritters.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I began once more to have flour meal. I always had plenty of flour meal in my days. Coffee and dried fruit in my days.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The only difference I notice was that there was a much greater variety—and the frozen foods and imported perishable foods—strawberries, etc.—were frozen—cabbage, onion, etc., imported during winter months and pressure cooking methods—all made great changes and shortened the housekeeper's time (which) shortened what work she did.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We always—from earliest recollection—bought every thing except a few potatoes, onions, and bacon. Bread was available once in 1886 or 1887. A few canned fruits as strawberries and canned jams—some times in the H.B. & Co. English and apple jars and mandarins—expression in food—tomatoes were the earliest canned vegetable—remember (above?) along in 1890 there were packaged jellies (something like jelly) but no desserts as now.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In my recollection as a child—Ontario—Ontario—when they had large stores of everything—goods and canned provisions in barrels, evaporated or dried apples in tins, raisins and currents in boxes (I believe) jams—these stores also had a store lot—a dear food—panty lace, ribbons—sometimes childrens' and ladies' hair hats as well as men's—pre-made clothes as far as I can remember—lots of pretty beads and gay collars and flannel blankets in red green or grey or white—the French and Indians loved these to wrap themselves. All the stores in pioneer days were several stores and carried a wide variety—including coal oil.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences or buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality of merchandise, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)
and candles, matches, etc. There was a great deal of "trading" in the early days. In my father's business the adventurers were thought of paying cash for the family "deal-out," any account they bought goods until the amount owing was paid. The farmers brought in a few bushels of potatoes, a couple hams (eggs and butter occasionally) and once I remember a load of wheat which we had made into flour at one of the mills where they did "grinding," as they called it, and paid them subscription—then pay—and paid them subscription—the pay—I never remember seeing much money they said when the railroad came it took over all the money—because freight had to be paid in cash instead of the "trading," the freighter used to do. When they really just got goods for their freight.

In addressing my envelope for this I recalled to mind that—When I was a kid just for a trip in 1897 there was not one building on the south side of the main street and only about three including the depot on the north side. The N.W.M. had a tavern I think named Willis located there.
and candles, pots, etc. Have no c.

we had most into play, or they called us

preyful need to do. But this

really got put food for their prosperity.
